p._value:
enc - symmetric
cipher routines

The symmetric
cipher commands allow data to be encrypted or decrypted
using various block and stream ciphers using keys based on
passwords or explicitly provided. Base64 encoding or
decoding can also be performed either by itself or in
addition to the encryption or decryption.

the input filename, standard
input by default.

the output filename, standard
output by default.

_values:

The program can

A password will
be prompted for to derive the key and

be
used if the key is being derived from a password unless you
want compatibility with previous versions of OpenSSL and
SSLeay.

option it is possible to perform efficient
dictionary attacks on the password and to attack stream
cipher encrypted data. The reason for this is that without
the salt the same password always generates the same
encryption key. When the salt is being used the first eight
bytes of the encrypted data are reserved for the salt: it is
generated at random when encrypting a file and read from the
encrypted file when it is decrypted.

Some of the
ciphers do not have large keys and others have security
implications if not used correctly. A beginner is advised to
just use a strong block cipher in

mode
such as bf or des3.

p._value:
All the block
ciphers normally use PKCS#5 padding also known as standard
block padding: this allows a rudimentary integrity or
password check to be performed. However since the chance of
random data passing the test is better than 1 in 256 it
isn’t a very good test.

If padding is
disabled then the input data must be a multiple of the
cipher block length.

_values:
ciphers have the same key and effective
key length.
des-ede-cbc Two key triple DES EDE in CBC mode
des-ede Two key triple DES EDE in ECB mode
des-ede-cfb Two key triple DES EDE in CFB mode
des-ede-ofb Two key triple DES EDE in OFB mode
des-ede3-cbc Three key triple DES EDE in CBC mode
des-ede3 Three key triple DES EDE in ECB mode
des-ede3-cfb Three key triple DES EDE CFB mode
des-ede3-ofb Three key triple DES EDE in OFB mode
idea-cbc IDEA algorithm in CBC mode
rc2-cbc 128 bit RC2 in CBC mode
rc2-cfb 128 bit RC2 in CFB mode
rc2-ecb 128 bit RC2 in ECB mode
rc2-ofb 128 bit RC2 in OFB mode
rc2-64-cbc 64 bit RC2 in CBC mode
rc2-40-cbc 40 bit RC2 in CBC mode
rc5-cbc RC5 cipher in CBC mode
rc5-cfb RC5 cipher in CFB mode
rc5-ecb RC5 cipher in ECB mode
rc5-ofb RC5 cipher in OFB mode
aes-[128|192|256]-cbc 128/192/256 bit AES in CBC mode

aes-[128|192|256]-cfb 128/192/256 bit AES in 128 bit CFB
mode
aes-[128|192|256]-cfb1 128/192/256 bit AES in 1 bit CFB mode
aes-[128|192|256]-cfb8 128/192/256 bit AES in 8 bit CFB mode
aes-[128|192|256]-ecb 128/192/256 bit AES in ECB mode
aes-[128|192|256]-ofb 128/192/256 bit AES in OFB mode

p._value:
Just base64
encode a binary file:

openssl base64
-in file.bin -out file.b64

Decode the same
file

openssl base64
-d -in file.b64 -out file.bin

openssl des3
-salt -in file.txt -out file.des3

Decrypt a file
using a supplied password:

openssl des3 -d
-salt -in file.des3 -out file.txt -k mypassword

_values:
Encrypt a file
then base64 encode it (so it can be sent via mail for
example) using Blowfish in

p._value:
openssl bf -a
-salt -in file.txt -out file.bf

Base64 decode a
file then decrypt it:

openssl bf -d
-salt -a -in file.bf -out file.txt

_values:
Decrypt some
data using a supplied 40 bit

p._value:
openssl rc4-40
-in file.rc4 -out file.txt -K 0102030405

_values:
option when used with large files doesn’t work

p._value:
There should be
an option to allow an iteration count to be included.

_values:
program only supports a fixed number of algorithms with
certain parameters. So if, for example, you want to use
with an 84 bit key you can’t use this program.

p._value: encrypt the input data: this is the default.
decrypt the input data.

base64 process the data. This means that if encryption
is taking place the data is base64 encoded after encryption.
If decryption is set then the input data is base64 decoded
before being decrypted.

_values:
option is set then base64 process the
data on one line.

used then
immediately exit: don’t do any encryption or
decryption.
